indicators.justification:
The assessment of this indicator is based on the policy frameworks from the Ministry of Environment and Forestry and laws governing emissions are aimed towards assessing the level of emissions and help the country adapt to climate change by reducing greenhouse gas emissions through mitigation of action plans to keep the levels lower than the projected trajectory, moving Kenya toward the low carbon pathway. Which will contribute towards sustainable 
development and green growth .

Sources
1.Kenya Air Quality and Emission Reduction Strategy 2020 
http://www.environment.go.ke/wp-content/uploads/2020/03/NCCAP_2018-2022_ExecutiveSummary-Compressed-1.pdf

2.The National Climate Change Action Plan 2018 - 2022 
http://www.environment.go.ke/wp-content/uploads/2020/03/NCCAP_2018-2022_ExecutiveSummary-Compressed-1.pdf

3. The Climate Change Act of 2016
http://kenyalaw.org/kl/fileadmin/pdfdownloads/Acts/ClimateChangeActNo11of2016.pdf

4. The Energy Act of 2019
http://kenyalaw.org/kl/fileadmin/pdfdownloads/Acts/2019/EnergyAct__No.1of2019.PDF

evidence.title: Kenya Air Quality and Emission Reduction Strategy 2020
The National Climate Change Action Plan 2018 - 2022

indicators.justification:
The assessment of this indicator is based on the Climate change Framework policy of 2017  by the Ministry of Environment and Natural Resources. A review of Climate Risks, Vulnerability, and Governance in Kenya of 2008–2012 by the United Development Programme (UNDP) and the Climate Risk Country Profiles developed by the World Bank Group which are all aimed to highlight Kenya's continuing vulnerability to climate change a enhance capacity to manage to identify critical gaps by recommending actions to better ensure the country's sustainable development objectives can be achieved.

Sources

1.Microsoft Word - Climate-Change-Framework-Policy(May2017).doc
http://www.environment.go.ke/wp-content/uploads/2018/08/Climate-Change-Framework-PolicyMay2017.pdf

2.Climate Risks, Vulnerability and Governance in Kenya: A review
https://www.iisd.org/system/files/publications/climate_risks_kenya.pdf

3.climate_risk_country_profile_kenya.pdf
https://www.acaps.org/sites/acaps/files/key-documents/files/climate_risk_country_profile_kenya.pdf

evidence.title: Climate Risks, Vulnerability and Governance in Kenya: A review

indicators.justification:
In the Assessment of this indicator, we find that the government currently does not provide updated information on civil registration and vital statistics. The available data that we find is also out of date and lacking several key indicators (such as mortality and marriage statistics) Necessary for the government to deploy a digitized CVRS System and increase capacity across the national and county governments to ensure that they are able to capture and release this information to the public.
Sources
1. 2019 Kenya Population and Housing Census Reports
https://www.knbs.or.ke/?p=5732

evidence.title: 2019 Kenya Population and Housing Census Reports

indicators.justification:
In the assessment of this indicator we are unable to find real-time health capacity data of the health care system in Kenya from government sources but find some information on the current status in a research article from the KEMRI-Wellcome Trust Research Programme on critical statistics on the hospital bed and ICU capacity in the country. The capacity of Kenyan hospitals to absorb increases in caseload due to COVID-19 is constrained by the availability of oxygen, with only 58% of hospital beds in hospitals with oxygen supply. Hence it is essential that the government is able to increase the number of hospital beds, ICU Units, Ventilator capacity, and medical staff in the event there is a spike in the number of cases. 

Source
Barasa EW, Ouma PO, Okiro EA (2020) Assessing the hospital surge capacity of the Kenyan health system in the face of the COVID-19 pandemic. PLoS ONE 15(7):
https://journals.plos.org/plosone/article?id=10.1371/journal.pone.0236308

indicators.justification: In the assessment of this indicator, we find that the Ministry of Health is providing detailed and up-to-date data on the Immunization  Status across the country. The report provides information on the vaccine supply, the total number of vaccinations; first and second dose administered, priority groups, disaggregated levels from  geographical regions, age, and gender.

indicators.justification: In the assessment of this indicator  we find that the laws of Kenya give a comprehensive framework that requires the collection and publication of consolidated public finance reports and data by relevant Government bodies in (1) the Constitution of Kenya,2010, (2) the Public Finance Management Act 2012 and this ensures full transparency and accountability. Citizens are made aware of the current state of affairs, how the government is acquiring its revenue, and the spending in a clear and annual basis.

evidence.title: The National Treasury and Planning - The Budget Summary for the Fiscal Year 2021/22 and Supporting Information
Estimates of Development Expenditure of the Government of Kenya for the year ending 30th June 2022.

responses.response_text: Data is available from government, or because of government actions.
responses.subquestion_text: Is this data available online in any form?
There is structured data available on the executive budget proposal in gross terms, including spending on annual and multi-annual investment projects.
There is structured data available on amended budgets (when applicable) or amendments of the enacted budget.
There is structured data available on the approved or enacted budget in gross terms, including spending on annual and multi-annual investment projects.
There is structured data about government budget execution or spending, in gross terms and on an accrual basis, including spending in annual and multi-annual investment projects.
There is structured data about the government's extrabudgetary funds spending, in gross terms and on an accrual basis.
There is structured data about the government's social security spending, in gross terms and on an accrual basis.
There is structured data about public corporations' spending, in gross terms and on an accrual basis.
Budget entries have administrative classifications to an internationally agreed standard.
Budget entries have economic classifications to an internationally agreed standard.
Budget entries have functional classifications to an internationally agreed standard.
Budget entries have program classifications according to an internationally agreed standard.
Information about individual financial transactions or expenditures is available at the most disaggregated level of the economic classification level.
Data is disaggregated by cross-cutting programs, or issues such as SDGs, climate action, gender budgeting, etc,
The data contains common identifiers to connect budget and budget performance data.
The data contains identifiers that can be used to connect budget data with data on major projects (e.g., infrastructure construction) and procurement processes.

Data is openly licensed.

indicators.justification:
The assessment of this indicator  has been carried out based on the Public Officer Ethics Act of 2003 which provides comprehensive  information on interest and asset declaration of public advance the ethics of public officers by providing for a Code of Conduct and Ethics and requiring financial declarations from certain public officers in Kenya. However, we find that this information has not been made available to the public and are unable to access any datasets on asset declaration

indicators.justification:
The Kenya Draft Policy On Public Participation of 2018 by the National Assembly and the Constitution of Kenya 2010 which provide a  comprehensive framework for the management and coordination of public participation in Kenya for the fulfilment of the constitutional requirement on citizen engagement in development and governance processes in the country. However it does not provide information on data sets and public comments generated through public consultation processes.

indicators.justification:
In the assessment of this indicator, open data on the Contracting and tendering process is made available in line with Open Contracting Data Standards only from Makueni County Government.  There is limited data on the comprehensive procurement process by the national government and other county governments and required data is unavailable to meet OCDS standards.
Source
1. Government of Makueni County Open Contracting Portal 
 https://opencontracting.makueni.go.ke/portal/tender

indicators.justification: Currently, we do not have any evidence to show that government efforts to support the reuse of data in all different capacities or with different stakeholders.

responses.response_text: There is no evidence of government supporting and encouraging data reuse.
responses.subquestion_text: Is there evidence of a government strategy to support and encourage data reuse?
There is evidence of government efforts to support open government data reuse.
There is evidence of government efforts to support big data reuse in a general sense.
There is evidence of government efforts to support private sector or NGO data reuse.
There is evidence of government efforts to support crowdsourced data reuse.
There is evidence of government efforts to support data reuse from various data topics.
There is evidence of government efforts to support data reuse by civil society organizations.
There is evidence of government efforts to support data reuse by media.
There is evidence of government efforts to support data reuse by scholars and academic institutions.
There is evidence of government efforts to support data reuse by the private sector.
Government support for data reuse involves data challenges.
Government support for data reuse involves hackathons.
Government support for data reuse involves communication and community building efforts.
Government support for data reuse involves running information sessions on how to use particular datasets, or how to reuse government data in general.
Government support for data reuse involves the release of funding schemes

indicators.justification:
The Kenya Open Data Initiative was launched in 2011 with the goal of supporting the Government's drive to consistently inform and be accountable to its citizens. In addition, the information shared by one Government office is also vital to other government stakeholders in the planning and implementation of their programs. However, they have not updated any datasets on the website since 2017 and there is no evidence for other support mechanisms e.g financial or training to national or county government in order to have a fully functional and up to date portal with relevant datasets on different sectors
Source
1. Kenya Open Data Portal
https://www.opendata.go.ke/

responses.response_text: There has been a government-led open government data initiative, but there is limited evidence of recent activity.
responses.subquestion_text: Has there been any form of government-led open government data initiative during the study period?
There is a government team in place supporting open data activities.
There is an allocated budget for open data activities.
There is a well-maintained open data portal.
There is guidance and support for government publication of open data.
Senior political leaders back the open data initiative.

indicators.justification: In the assessment of this indicator, we find no evidence of cities or local governments having sufficient capacity to collect and publish open data with the government. There are also no laws or regulations that require data be held open to the public

responses.response_text: There is no evidence of capability to effectively manage data.
responses.subquestion_text: To what extent do city, regional, and local governments have the capability to effectively manage data?
There is evidence of local governments having open data initiatives.
There is evidence of local governments having current open data policies in place.
There is evidence of local governments having rules and or guidance in place to provide a comprehensive framework for data sharing.
There is evidence of local governments having rules and or guidance in place for consistent data management and publication.
There is evidence of local governments providing training to civil servants on data literacy and skills.
There is evidence of local governments providing support for data reuse.

responses.response_text: No cities or regions show capacity to effectively manage data.
responses.subquestion_text: How widespread are local capacities to effectively manage data?

indicators.justification:
There is some evidence that the government is providing some training through the Kenya School of Government and Public Service Commission. The Government of Kenya recognizes the importance of human resource development as a means towards efficiency and effectiveness in the delivery of public services. In order to maintain and enhance the momentum towards greater productivity, the government pursues a policy of continually upgrading staff competencies, knowledge, skills and attitude, with the aim of addressing identified performance gaps.

Sources
1.The Kenya School of Government
https://ksg.ac.ke/wp-content/uploads/2021/03/KSG-Strategic-Plan.pdf
2.Guidelines On Managing Training In The Public Service
https://www.publicservice.go.ke › category › 62-g

evidence.title: Guidelines On Managing Training In The Public Service

responses.response_text: There is isolated evidence of government supporting civil servants training on data matters.
responses.subquestion_text: Is there evidence of  government´s actions to train civil servants on data matters?
Training delivered covers data frameworks and governance topics.
Training delivered to public servants covers topics on data gathering.
Training delivered covers data analysis, visualisations and storytelling techniques.
Training delivered covers specific technical topics for data centred roles.
Training on data addresses non-technical public servants.
Training on data is focused on specific positions already working with data.
Training is planned by an established training team, department, or agency.
Public servants receive a certification when taking a training so there is a formal recognition as a professional development.

indicators.justification: There is currently no online data political integrity

responses.response_text: The datasets do not share common identifiers.
responses.subquestion_text: There is evidence that datasets share common identifiers.
The key datasets for this theme share common identifiers that facilitate mapping flows across the data ecosystem.
The different political integrity datasets use common identifiers for public officials.
Lobbying data and political finance data share common identifiers for lobbyist clients and party and campaign donors.
Lobbying registers and public consultation data use common identifiers for regulations.
Asset declarations and political finance disclosures share common identifiers for interests, assets, and liabilities.
The various datasets share common identifiers for legal persons associated with donations, interests, assets, liabilities, and lobbying activities.
The key datasets for the political integrity and company information modules share common identifiers that facilitate mapping flows across the data ecosystem.
The key datasets for the political integrity and land modules share common identifiers that facilitate mapping flows across the data ecosystem.
The key datasets for the political integrity and public finance modules share common identifiers that facilitate mapping flows across the data ecosystem.
The key datasets for the political integrity and public procurement modules share common identifiers that facilitate mapping flows across the data ecosystem.

indicators.justification:
In the assessment of this indicator, there are comprehensive laws and regulations on the collection of beneficial ownership data by the Business Registration Service but the laws restrict access to this data; and the information would only be accessible under special consideration

Definitions comprehensively cover ownership.
Definitions cover control.
Rules or processes exist to protect certain natural persons who are beneficial owners from having their data published.

indicators.justification: There are laws and regulations that require that data collection and publication be accessible to people with disabilities in the Data Protection Act 2019 (Section 26 and 27) and The Access to Information Act 2016 (Section 8 and 28) by ensuring that the data controllers shall take the necessary steps to ensure that the individuals with disabilities are given special consideration and protected in a manner that meets their needs.

responses.response_text: A framework exists and has the force of law.
responses.subquestion_text: What is the nature of the framework?

responses.response_text: There is either a dedicated framework for accessibility coverage related to data or a framework that includes specific provisions related to accessibility coverage and data.
responses.subquestion_text: Where does this requirement exist?
The rules/guidance empower an agency or official to ensure the accurate and timely collection and publication of required data.
The framework requires a verification process.
How comprehensive, in terms of jurisdiction, is the coverage of the laws, regulations, policies, or guidance assessed for this question?

indicators.justification:
The assessment of this indicator is based on the laws and policies by the Government of Kenya on data management and publication indicated in the Data Protection Act 2019, the Access to Information Act 2016, and the Privacy and Data Protection Policy 2018. These laws provide for the strict collection, use, and transfer of personal data while ensuring they are kept up to date and maintained in accordance with the provisions of the various mandates. This ensures that data controllers are processing personal data of a
data subject guided by the principles set out in the various laws in Kenya.
Sources
1. The Data Protection Act 2019

2. The Access to Information Act 2016

3. The Privacy and Data Protection Policy 2018.
https://www.ca.go.ke/wp-content/uploads/2018/09/Privacy-and-Data-Protection-Policy-2018.pdf

responses.response_text: A framework exists and has the force of law.
responses.subquestion_text: What is the nature of the framework?
There are minimum standards for metadata when government data is catalogued or published.
There is a standardised process for publishing and updating published government data.
There are technical standards, including common data models, codelists, and identifiers for management and publication of government data.
There are clearly documented quality control processes for government data.
There are clearly documented processes for soliciting and integrating feedback from external users to improve data quality.

responses.response_text: The data management approaches assessed generally apply across the whole public sector.
responses.subquestion_text: How broadly is good data management practice established?

indicators.justification:
The assessment of this indicator has been conducted based on the Laws enacted by the Government of Kenya to regulate data sharing through the Data Protection Act 2019, the Constitution of Kenya 2010, and the Data  Protection General Regulations of 2021. These laws provide for the protection of personal data by giving strict regulations in which third parties are able to access and share citizens' data in a manner that does not infringe on their individual rights.
Sources
1. Data Protection Act 2019
http://kenyalaw.org/kl/fileadmin/pdfdownloads/Acts/2019/TheDataProtectionAct__No24of2019.pdf

responses.response_text: A framework exists and has the force of law.
responses.subquestion_text: What is the nature of the framework?
The framework covers data sharing within government.
The framework covers how government should share data with other sectors.
The framework covers data sharing from other sectors to government.
The framework covers data sharing within the private sector.
The framework explicitly focuses on artificial intelligence uses of data.

responses.response_text: The framework assessed covers all government agencies, and many themes.
responses.subquestion_text: How broad is the coverage of legal or policy frameworks for data sharing for the public good?
How comprehensive, in terms of jurisdiction, is the coverage of the laws, regulations, policies, or guidance assessed for this question?

indicators.justification:
The assessment of this indicator has been based on the Laws enacted by the Government of Kenya to regulate the collection and processing of data in Kenya through the Data Protection Act of 2019.

The Act was established by the Parliament of Kenya to develop a comprehensive framework for the provision for the regulation of the processing of personal data, to provide for the rights of data subjects and obligations of data controllers and processors in Kenya.
"To give effect to Article 31(c) and (d) of the Constitution; to establish the Office of the Data Protection Commissioner; to make provision for the regulation of the processing of personal data; to provide for the rights of data subjects and obligations of data controllers and processors; and for connected purposes."

Sources
(1) Data Protection Act.2019. http://kenyalaw.org/kl/fileadmin/pdfdownloads/Acts/2019/TheDataProtectionAct__No24of2019.pdf

responses.response_text: A framework exists and has the force of law.
responses.subquestion_text: What is the nature of the framework?
The framework provides data subjects with rights of choice or consent.
The framework provides data subjects with rights to access and correct data about themselves.
The framework sets out clear responsibilities for data holders.
The framework provides rights of redress
The framework requires data controllers to notify an appropriate authority of data breaches.
Frameworks explicitly cover the protection of location-related data.
The framework addresses algorithmic decision making.
Exceptions to the usual data protection framework have been made as part of the country's COVID-19 response.

responses.response_text: The framework applies widely across all sectors (including public and private sector).
responses.subquestion_text: How broadly does this data protection framework apply?

responses.response_text: The framework assessed, or equivalent frameworks, apply across the whole country.
responses.subquestion_text: Does this framework apply across the whole country?

indicators.justification: In the assessment of this indicator, we find that currently there are no laws or regulations that require Government Ministries and Agencies to collect and publish data in the required National Languages. The Constitution of Kenya 2010 states that the National Language is Kiswahili while the country's official languages are English and Kiswahili. This necessitates that information is relayed through these languages.

responses.subquestion_text: What is the nature of the framework?
Where does this requirement exist?
The rules/guidance empower an agency or official to ensure the accurate and timely collection and publication of required data.
The framework requires a verification process.

indicators.justification: There are no laws and regulations in place requiring government ministries or agencies to publish information as open data. However, The Kenya Open Data Initiative from the ICT Authority has created a Kenya Open Data Portal that provides datasets on different sectors that are freely accessible in reusable formats. Currently, the site is dormant and The datasets are up to year 2017.

responses.subquestion_text: What is the nature of the framework?
The framework establishes a common definition of open data.
The framework promotes open licensing without any restrictions beyond attribution and share-alike.
The framework requires to publish data in machine readable formats.
The rules/guidance requires the use of specific data standards.
The framework promotes training and capacity building among government officials.

indicators.justification:
In the assessment of this indicator, we find that the laws of Kenya provide a clear and comprehensive framework for public bodies to publish information on public finance data as required by the Constitution of Kenya and the Public Finance Management Act 2012. This is to ensure transparent and effective management of public funds, promoting accountability and ensuring that all this information of budgeting and spending  is easily accessible to all citizens
Sources
1. The Constitution of Kenya 2010

responses.subquestion_text: Are there laws, policies, or regulations requiring collection or publication of this information in any form?

responses.response_text: Requirements to publish data are set out in non-binding policy or guidance.
responses.subquestion_text: Do relevant laws, policies, regulations, or guidance discuss the publication of open data?
Summary reports must be provided as structured data.
Expenditure information at the most disaggregated level of the economic classification must be provided as structured data.
The rules/guidance require executive budget proposal information to be provided as structured data.
The rules/guidance require the approved or enacted budget to be provided as structured data.
The rules/guidance require in-year reports as structured data.
The rules/guidance require year-end reports as structured data.
The rules/guidance empower an agency or official to ensure the accurate and timely collection and publication of required data.
The framework requires a verification process.
The rules/guidance require that data is regularly updated.
The rules/guidance support the collection of structured data.

responses.response_text: The laws, regulations, policies or guidance assessed, or equivalent rules/guidance, apply across the whole public sector including national, sub-national, and local government.
responses.subquestion_text: How comprehensive is the coverage of laws, regulations, policies, or guidance assessed for this question?

indicators.justification:
The assessment of this indicator has been conducted based on the Laws enacted by the Government of Kenya to advance the ethics of public officers by providing for a Code of Conduct and Ethics for public officers in Kenya. However, the act only specifies collecting data on the interest and assets of public officials but not publishing the collected data. The says that 
the contents of a declaration shall be accessible to any person upon application, but also says that no information obtained shall be published or in any way made public, establishing sanctions to those who do not comply (art 30).

Source
1.The Public Officer Ethics Act,2003
http://kenyalaw.org/kl/fileadmin/pdfdownloads/Acts/PublicOfficerEthicsAct.pdf

indicators.justification:
The assessment of this indicator is based on the  Political Parties Act, 2011 and the Kenya Constitution 2010 .The Act gives legal and regulatory framework for registration, regulation and funding of political parties in Kenya which  the primary legal reference for management of political parties in accordance with Articles 91 and 92 of the Kenya Constitution 2010, which envisages well governed political parties that respect internal democracy and their constitutional status in the Kenyan political system. 

Sources
1.The Political Parties Act, 2011
http://kenyalaw.org/kl/fileadmin/pdfdownloads/Acts/PoliticalPartiesAct.pdf
2.The Constitution of Kenya 
http://parliament.go.ke/sites/default/files/2017-05/The_Constitution_of_Kenya_2010.pdf

indicators.justification:
The assessment of this indicator  has been carried out based on The Kenya Draft Policy On Public Participation of 2018 by the National Assembly and the Constitution of Kenya 2010 which provide a framework for the management and coordination of public participation in Kenya for the fulfilment of the constitutional requirement on citizen engagement in development and governance processes in the country.

indicators.justification:
The assessment of this indicator was based on the Constitution of Kenya 2010 and the Access to Information ACT 2016 as the regulatory framework in kenya. indicators.justification:
Currently, there is no evidence of the use of political integrity data in Kenya being to identify, expose, or highlight failures of government online. However, some organizations such as Mzalendo Trust, Transparency International and Westminister Foundation for Democracy are  keen on providing oversite over the National Assembly and Senate and providing the public with vital information on legislation and resources providing factual information for citizens online and for offline political engagements
